sect1.title: CASE 52
sect1.para: The patient was a 27-year-old Caucasian male who was transferred from a hospital in eastern North Carolina, where he lived in a small rural town with his mother. He worked in hog processing as a meat inspector. He moved from Ohio to North Carolina approximately 3 years ago. He gave a rather vague and contradictory history concerning opioid use while in Ohio.

One day prior to his transfer, he awoke with a severe headache and neck pain that prevented him from going to work. He felt better during the day, but the morning of his admission, he again awoke with a severe headache (the “worst of his life”) and presented to the emergency department (ED) of an outside hospital. A head computed tomography (CT) scan indicated an intracranial bleed. Because no neurosurgeon was available, he was transferred to a tertiary hospital where he was taken emergently to the operating room (OR). There a middle cerebral artery aneurysm was detected and repaired, with blood evacuated from the brain.

On physical examination 2 days postsurgery, his vital signs were within normal limits, as were his complete blood count and metabolic panel. He denied fever; chills; night sweats; weight loss; or pain in his chest, abdomen, back, or joints prior to admission. He did not have any skin rashes, and his nail beds were normal. Importantly, on physical examination, he was noted to have a grade 3 over 6 systolic murmur coupled with poor dentition. When the systolic murmur was noted, he had a transthoracic echocardiogram that showed a large mitral valve vegetation. Two blood cultures were ordered, as well as HIV and hepatitis A, B, and C serologies. He was started on two antibiotics: vancomycin and ceftriaxone.

listitem.para: 1. What does a large vegetation on the mitral valve indicate?
2. This condition is being seen with much greater frequency in the United States, particularly in Appalachia. Why?
3. Given the presence of the large vegetation, what is the significance of the patient’s poor dentition?
4. Why were two blood cultures obtained?
5. The patient was given “empiric” antimicrobial therapy. What is that? Why specifically was he given vancomycin and ceftriaxone? What gaps are there in his empiric therapy?

sect1.para: After 14 hours’ incubation, an organism was detected in the patient’s blood culture (Fig. 52.1).

textobject.para: A microscopic tissue sample showing numerous stained structures, with some filamentous or rod-shaped elements, suggestive of a bacterial or protozoan infection within cells.

listitem.para: 6. Based on his history, his echocardiogram results, and his blood culture Gram stain results, what organism is the most likely cause of his infection?
7. Based on the Gram stain results, did the patient’s antimicrobial therapy need to be changed?

sect1.para: The results of his HIV and hepatitis A, B, and C serologies indicated he was negative for HIV, hepatitis A, and hepatitis B antibodies but positive for the presence of hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibodies.

listitem.para: 8. How do these results help you understand this case and the organism found in his bloodstream?

sect1.para: On the second hospital day, his blood culture isolate was growing on a sheep blood agar plate (Fig. 52.2).

figure.title: Figure 52.2 Blood culture isolate on sheep blood agar plate.

textobject.para: A photograph showing a reddish medium with bacterial growth, including streaks and colonies, indicative of a bacterial culture.

listitem.para: 9. An optochin test was done on this organism, and it was found to be resistant. What organism was most likely causing his infection based on this information?

sect1.para: The following susceptibility results were reported:

listitem.para: Penicillin G Intermediate
Ceftriaxone Susceptible
Vancomycin Susceptible
10. Based on these susceptibility results, how might his antimicrobial therapy be altered?

11. When consulted, an infectious disease (ID) consultant noted that the patient had poor valvular function. She recommended a specific surgical procedure for this patient. What is it, and why was it recommended?

sect1.para: On the fifth hospital day, the patient was noted to have a seizure, and on physical examination his left pupil was fixed. A head CT was done and is seen in Fig. 52.3. He was taken to the OR, where a second middle cerebral artery aneurysm was located and repaired and a large blood clot was removed from his brain.

listitem.para: 12. How was the patient’s infection related to this new complication?

sect1.para: He was taken to the OR, where surgery was done to treat the lesion seen on CT. Over the next 10 days the patient slowly improved, but on the 16th hospital day he was found by a nurse practitioner on routine rounds to be unresponsive. A code was called and the patient was intubated. A head CT showed that he had a massive bleed into his head. In a family conference, the clinician told the family that after this event he was not likely to regain any meaningful mental function. They agreed to a “do not resuscitate” order. The patient slowly deteriorated and died 7 days later.

textobject.para: A scan showing symmetrical brain structures with areas of abnormal hyperintensity, possibly indicating brain pathology such as swelling, lesion, or hemorrhage.

sect1.para: 1. A vegetation is a pathologic lesion seen in patients with endocarditis. The infection begins with a defect in one of the heart valves, resulting in turbulent blood flow. This may result in deposition of platelets and fibrin, to which “sticky” organisms may bind during a transient bacteremia. A common culprit is viridans group streptococci (VGS), which are predominant in dental plaque. As bacteria divide and increasing amounts of fibrin and platelets adhere, the vegetation grows until it can be visualized by echocardiogram.

2. An increasing number of individuals have opioid use disorder in the United States, with high rates being reported in states along the Appalachian Mountains (1). Initially the patients may have received long-acting opioids to treat pain. Unfortunately, the use of long-acting opioids often results in addiction to opioids. When addicted individuals can no longer obtain the drugs legally, they may turn to street drugs, especially heroin. These street drugs are frequently not sterile, and a variety of organisms can be associated with their injection. Alternatively, organisms can be introduced during injection secondary to licking the needle, contamination of fluids used to dissolve the street drugs, or injecting through a contaminated site. A significant increase in the number of endocarditis cases is being seen in this population (2).

3. Patients with poor dentition often develop transient bacteremia, especially when brushing teeth. The most common bacteria involved are members of the VGS. These organisms are an important component of dental plaque. VGS have polysaccharides on their surface that mediate adherence to the tooth surface as well as other organisms—these polysaccharides likely also mediate adherence to heart valves that have been damaged by injection of drugs, resulting in vegetations on the surface of the heart valve.

4. Patients who have endocarditis have “continuous bacteremia,” in that bacteria are constantly being shed from the heart valve and enter the bloodstream. In patients with endocarditis, all blood cultures will be positive. In some patients who have multiple blood cultures, only one may be positive for organisms that are part of the skin microbiota or can cause transient bacteremia following tooth brushing. Since VGS is among those organisms that might be found transiently, it is important to determine if the organism is present transiently or continuously. Patients with transient bacteremia or skin contamination will typically have only one of two positive blood cultures, while those with continuous bacteremia will have the same organism in both cultures.

5. Empiric therapy is treatment administered based on philosophy, experience, or prior knowledge, and is given when the specific cause of an infection is unknown. The choice of which antimicrobials to use is based on the likelihood that they will inhibit or kill the most common organisms expected to be the cause of the infection. In this case, the antibiotics chosen were vancomycin, which will kill most Gram-positive organisms, and ceftriaxone, which will kill most Gram-negative organisms that can cause endocarditis. A gap in empiric therapy would occur if the patient had vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus, or VRE. The most common species of VRE is Enterococcus faecium. Since Enterococcus makes up only 10% of isolates that cause endocarditis in substance use disorder (SUD) and not all are E. faecium, the patient’s risk is small (3). Two other organisms that would not be covered by this therapy are Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Candida albicans, each of which is found in 5% of individuals with SUD-associated endocarditis (3).
6. The organism is most likely one of the VGS. VGS are Gram-positive cocci that are organized in pairs or short chains. Another possibility would be an Enterococcus sp.

7. VGS are reliably susceptible to both vancomycin and ceftriaxone. At this point, it would not be unreasonable to de-escalate the antimicrobial therapy to one of the two cell wall antimicrobials; which agent is preferred is difficult to say based on the evidence, although ceftriaxone tends to be more bactericidal against VGS compared with vancomycin.

8. The most frequent mode of transmission of HCV is injection drug use, specifically, sharing a needle with an HCV-infected individual. Because opioid addiction is often not well documented in patient medical records, epidemiologic studies use HCV infection as a surrogate for SUD. The patient belongs to the demographic group most frequently associated with SUD: rural Caucasians between 18 and 44 years of age (4). The most common cause of bacterial endocarditis in this group is Staphylococcus aureus, frequently secondary to skin or soft tissue infections. In this case, the source of the bacteria that caused his infection was most likely his poor dentition. His prior drug use may have damaged his mitral valve, creating an abnormality on which a vegetation could form and the VGS could adhere.

9. Optochin (ethylhydrocupreine hydrochloride) is a chemical that can be used to presumptively identify alpha hemolytic streptococci. All strains of VGS are resistant to optochin, while Streptococcus pneumoniae is susceptible. Given that the organism was an optochin resistant, α-hemolytic, Gram-positive coccus in chains, the most likely identification is VGS. Enterococcus spp. are occasionally α-hemolytic as well as vancomycin resistant, so a confirmatory identification was performed using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). The organism was identified as belonging to the Streptococcus sanguis group which are oral alpha hemolytic streptococci.

10. Since the organism is susceptible to both ceftriaxone and vancomycin, either one could be chosen based on current clinical practice guidelines. However, ceftriaxone dosing is less frequent and vancomycin requires monitoring for toxicity, so ceftriaxone was chosen. The consulting infectious disease team added 2 weeks of gentamicin to the patient’s therapy with the idea that gentamicin would be synergistic with ceftriaxone. Although Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) endocarditis clinical practice guidelines recommend the combination of penicillin and gentamicin, there is no recommendation for the use of gentamicin with ceftriaxone (5). Again because of potential toxicity, gentamicin levels need to be monitored.

11. Because the patient had a stroke secondary to his endocarditis, the ID consultant recommended the replacement of his mitral valve to reduce the risk of additional embolic events by removing the valve with vegetations that could embolize. In patients with stroke, valve replacement should be delayed for 4 weeks while the infection is being treated to minimize the risk of infectious emboli and contamination of the replacement valve.

12. The aneurysm was likely the result of a septic embolus in which a small fragment of infected tissue released from the vegetation on his heart valve and lodged in an artery, resulting in inflammation, ischemia, and weakening of the arterial wall resulting in blood leaking into tissue. Approximately 90% of septic emboli from the mitral valve lodge in the middle cerebral artery.

listitem.para: A characteristic pathologic lesion of bacterial or fungal endocarditis is a vegetation. A vegetation adhering to the heart valve is composed of platelets, fibrin, neutrophils, and bacteria or rarely yeasts or molds.

This patient had a native mitral valve endocarditis. Poor dentition, which this patient had, is a key risk factor for endocarditis. The patient belonged to a demographic group in whom opioid use disorder is most common, Caucasians between 18 and 44 years of age who live in rural areas. His positive hepatitis C serology further supports that he may have been injecting drugs.

The most likely etiology of endocarditis in patients with poor dentition is VGS. VGS are predominant in the oral cavity, and people with poor dentition frequently have transient bacteremia with VGS. Intravenous drug use can damage heart valves, resulting in the initiation of vegetation formation by platelets. VGS, which have surface carbohydrates that allow them to form biofilms, can adhere to the vegetation.
Treatment of endocarditis is long term, usually 6 weeks, and is dependent upon the antimicrobial susceptibility of the infecting organism.

Two key diagnostic tools in the diagnosis of endocarditis are echocardiograms, which allow the detection of vegetation on heart valves, and blood cultures, which allow the determination of the etiology of infection.
This patient had a stroke secondary to a septic embolus. Central cerebral artery aneurysms are found in 90% of individuals who have strokes secondary to septic emboli.
The number of cases of bacterial endocarditis has greatly increased in the United States over the past 5 years, with opioid use being a major contributing factor to that increase.
